Really wanted to love this one since MMO's are my favorite non-VR genre, but I'll give the pros and cons and you can decide.

Pros:
-Devoted developers who are constantly updating the game
-Fantastic community, friendliest community of any game I've ever played
-The only VR MMORPG right now, and it has most of the traditional MMO features like quests, classes/roles, progression, gear, dungeons, professions, even PvP and more.
-Lots of players around the main town, so the game isn't dead

Cons:
-Tutorial/new player experience is much better than it used to be, but still insufficient.  The first several hours in the game are a mixture of tedious and confusing (luckily lots of helpful people around).
-While there are many players around the main town, I wasn't able to join a dungeon or battleground at all.  Maybe not enough people in queue, or maybe bugged.  Don't know, but I tried both and waited a long time before giving up.
-And finally the main issue: The combat just isn't fun, especially compared a number of other VR games.  My guess is this was to ensure Orbus runs on almost anything, but the lack of any kind of physics or feedback makes combat feel lifeless.  While I'm sure the devs will keep working on/improving the game, I very much doubt this one is possible to change at this point.

Bottom line: if you want a VR MMORPG, this is your only option for now and the near future.  It isn't terrible, but I hope in a year or two we have at least one other more impressive option.

review_title: Casual MMO with Much More Under the Hood

Dungeons are an enjoyable experience (except for the mouth breathers or quitters) and while I haven't tried the new raid yet (still gearing myself in the challenge versions of dungeons) the world boss was a wild experience. Fellow players are nice and will help you out if you ask, and since there is intentionally not an online guide anywhere you will definitely be asking or else figuring things out through trial and error. The graphics are cartoon-esque and a little bland until you start venturing farther from the main city and see some really neat environments. The game does feel like it's in perpetual Beta - but that's sort of how MMOs work - as there are regular patches/updates for classes or content at no extra cost or subscription fee. You thankfully don't have to reroll to change your class; you can level up all the classes on your one toon so you don't have to redo reputations or keep track of multiple inventories. I've invested probably 40 hours into the game so far and it's a lot of fun; just get over that first hurdle of the learning curve and you'll find the Reborn world engaging and fun as well. :)

one_reviews_text:
There's a lot of people here conflating awkward with challenging.  The game designers thought up some neat interactions with the most of the classes but lack either the skill or the tech to deliver.

Class development doesn't really change over the course of your leveling so you're lacking a any type of real character progression other than watching some arbitrary numbers go up. Some of the classes are severely boring to play with only a small number of abilities meaning there's not much adaptation you can do to different enemies/situations, you just repeat the same 3-4 moves for the entirety of your gameplay.

Most of the "skill" required in the class is actually a mix of moving your controller in just the right directions in sequence and a little bit of luck in whether the game actually registers your movement correctly (it frequently does not).

The interface design is somewhat terrible with your different skills placed often times in the most inconvenient of places without any way of moving things around. For example a shaman must reach down to grab an orb from the top of a totem they've thrown down so they can throw the orb at the enemy. Your totem bar for throwing down a new totem is placed right at your waist making it super easy to grab a totem instead of the orb which resets the orb spawn timer despawning the orb you could have thrown. 

Ultimately this game feels like it needs another year or so of design/development. Pick up this game if your idea of a good time is working around poor design, avoid otherwise.

My first impressions of this game after a few hours of playtime are, it's worth the money and will likely keep me entertained for many, many hours. The combat technique of all the classes are unique and take advantage of you being in VR, The warrior for example you have a sword and shield, you need to time your attacks and blocks right to be effective, the ranger has a bow and arrow so accuracy is key, the mage has a wand and is one of the hardest classes to play, not only do you need to memorise the spells, you then have to draw them in the air to cast them, none of this simple press a button and your attack fires like a 2d MMO, this game takes skill.

The crafting in game requires you to physically grab the items and craft with them, whether it's potion making, following instructions you found and dropping the items into the couldren, in the correct order, or making lures for fishing by combining certain ingrediants to attract certain fish.

To collect resources you have to physically mine them when your harvest tool, to fish you need to cast your rod and reel it in, careful not to break the line, to race your dragon (yes, there's dragon racing) you have to use your head to guide them through the course.

I'm really looking forward to seeing what this game truely has to offer, I've not even got a full set of gear yet, but I've had a quick go with all the different weapons to see their playstyle and tried lots of little bits the game has to offer. There's still much more for me to explore like all the story missions, bigger world events and even 4 x 5 man dungeons to take on with friends who are picking up the game

The only real negative I have to say about the game is the graphics, the character models kind of look like they escaped from the nintendo Mii factory and the world itself certainly isn't going to have you simply staring at it for hours, but I can overlook graphics in a groundbreaking game, made for a niche market. This is currently the only MMORPG available for VR, and thankfully it's pretty darn good. The three most important parts of an MMORPG in my opinion are Combat, Community, and Content (The Three C's of MMORPGs!).

Combat: Some of the best for VR in my opinion. Warriors swing a sword and have a shield, combos based on directional swinging. Archers work like normal. Musketeers have a gun they can load special ammo into the front of. RuneMages use gesture based casting for over 10 spells using their wand (more like drawing). With 3 sensors I have had no issues in combat.

Community: Literally the best community out of any game ever. You can go up to just about anyone and ask for help and they'll help you. If you ask a random person where something is, there's a 50% chance they'll give you directions, and a 50% chance they'll lead you there themselves. I haven't met a single rude person on here.

Content: The bane of many VR games is that they're good, but they're short. The bane of many MMORPGs is that there's more grinding that actually playing the game. A VR MMORPG has a lot of potential to be very bad, but thankfully, the devs understand what consumers want. The world is huge. Just walking without a mount, it'd probably take a good 15-20 minutes to get from one end to the other. There are a lot of unique enemies with different move-sets. There a ton of dungeons, and there are even world bosses. Grind is present, but it's not overwhelming at all. You can almost max out a class just doing the main story line. There are a ton of sidequests as well.

Finally, the #1 best part about this game, is the devs. They communicate a lot, ask what we want, listen to feedback, and constantly improve the game. You know what the devs are doing with the money they earned from early access purchases? Completely overhauling the game. Straight up remaking it to be completely better in every aspect. Better mechanics, graphics, customization, more classes, more content, everything.
if this was a flat MMO, it would be a c+, but easily is one of the best VR titles out there. The re-do also has just about doubled content and was done very nicly.

it's not that it's a bad game and i can't see no one having fun, the main issue is the absurd price for a game that looks like it cost less to make.

VR's only MMO leaves a lot to be desired. If you're a seasoned RPG/MMO player looking for an immersive fantasy experience that incites a sense of wonder, danger, magic, and rewarding combat, then Orbus -- in its current state -- may be very disappointing for you.

Once you familiarize yourself with the core mechanics and gameplay (by the time you get to Guild City), you may find yourself asking, "Why did I spend 40 bucks on this game?".  Here is why.

Immersion:
Everytime you open your journal and see an untextured square block of a page with an arial'ish type font on it; everytime you loot an item and open your inventory only to see a plain, uninspired, blocky-MS Paint-interface; and everytime you exit your house and have your eardrums ruptured by the random conversations of other players, your experience suffers. 

What little immersion the actual world of Orbus provides is quickly ruined by their horrible UI, graphics, stale combat, boring storyline (the physical in-game characters look nothing like their art in the cutscenes--Oscar has an earring in-game but doesn’t in cutscenes?), poor voice acting that doesn’t match cutscene art, and the mics of surrounding players (yeah, you can just mute everyone but still).

Combat: 
Boring. Once you figure out how to use the weapons there isn't anything exciting about your interaction with monsters. They come toward you and you spam them down. That is it. No satisfying dodge or timed blocks, no reflecting magical attacks, no grappling, controller buzzing when you release your drawn arrow. There is absolutely no difference in monster behavior. They all feel the same and you will feel the same despite leveling up and collecting gear.

Graphics:
This game very much looks and feels like Nintendo 64 Pokemon. If you’re a 32 year old man like me, this isn’t nostalgic, it is depressing.

I own many titles and many have tracking issues upon release, but they work out the bugs within a few month.  Orbus has not. 
eg. As i'm playing FalloutVR i can be facing ANY DIRECTION, be close OR far from the sensors, lean over, back, under and over with ZERO sensor or controller latency. And the graphic are so much more cpu intense then this game. But yet its still increibly polished and smooth. The only reason i bring up another title is if THEY can do it then it can be easily done - if the Devs care, leaving me to assume that it is low on the Orbus very long "todo" list.

I am not a tech guy, and I am just saying what I feel is lacking in the combat of orbus and why I don’t find it fun (so please don’t get offended if you believe the combat in orbus is perfect and believe it’s not possible to improve). In others word, I’m just saying what I think can help make the combat system more fun. review_title: A promising start for VR MMOs
one_reviews_text:
As a Non-MMO player who was always interested in playing MMOs but never having had the time or funds to get involved. Coming across Orbus VR was a dream come true, the first time jumping into the game and wandering around the town, just to have someone walk past and say hey made me stop for a minute and just take it in, later that evening I spent about an hour or so fishing with a couple of other low levels just chatting and helping each other out. This is the first time I've felt so connected to a living breathing world, where you can chat to travellers along the road help each other out with quests and knowledge and team up in such a natural and realistic fashion.
The experience is incredible, the combat feels engaging and challenging for most classes, the world while a bit bare feels so alive due to the people you meet along the way and the emphasis on cooperation and collaboration works so well with how helpful and engaged most of the community is. 
The game isn't perfect, but it gives a glimpse of what the future holds for vr multiplayer games and I honestly can't wait.
The devs are active and engaged with the community, the majority of players are either long time MMO players who've been waiting for a game like this for years, or new players who've become immersed and involved with the game. So the vast majority of the community is excited, happy to be there and help out. 
The only major issue with the game as I see it is the reliance on the community, there's not enough substance to get an enjoyable gameplay going at it solo, and there will be a point where you become blocked off from content unless you join up with other players, which as with all communitys is mostly great but with a few jerks scattered about and an early players experience with the few bad ones will likely ruin their impressions of the game.

This is too early to be sold at full price. 

Graphics aren't everything...

...but some of these models are substandard, even for placeholders. There really isn't a cohesive art stlye to speak of; that is unless 'baby's first 3d project' is a new motif.

There's a lot of glitchy quest related stuff. I remember one playthrough where the gathering mechanic just simply 'turned off' for me and required a restart. Not a big deal, but load times for this game are a special kind of hell.

The spell book stays floating in the air when you put it away. So if you stow it on your back, it will just stupidly defy physics and hang around in that same location until you move far enough away.

Audio is atrocious in this game. Absolutely horrid. There are NPCs that will repeat the same annoying phrases (at ear murderous volumes) over, and over and over and over.. 

This game is Duplo legos. Hell, it's not even Duplo. It's like buying a lego set and getting a box full of disembodied lego people heads. 

I get it. It's early access. I respect the immense amount of work that goes into the development of such a large scale project.. but for the asking price? I feel like an unpaid intern testing a prototype. To the devs: I'm sorry to dump on your hard work, but seriously- take a step back and ask yourselves: is this REALLY the game you wanted to make?

If it sounds like I'm being harsh it's becuase there are other VR games like onward that were built with the same set of tools, made by a single person, hosted on end user computers and run almost flawlessly with acceptable graphics and hours of more engaging gameplay than this game.

Okay.  As always, keep in mind that this is an early access review.

I've been playing Orbus through the beta/alpha and now early access.  My core responses are that I love this game.  I would recommend it to anyone who loves the mmo, fantasy genrre, or loves VR. 

This is a true VR game.  It isn't a ported over MMO converted to run in VR.  The game was designed from the bottom up with all the mechanics developed to be used in a VR environment.  They have proved that this genre (VR MMO) is not only workable and possible but extremely fun.

Having said that, this game is a not a AAA mmo.  Anyone who is coming to it with  the expectation that it is going to be a big release with dozens of servers and thousands of players is totally misunderstanding the niche that this game is playing to.  To be frank, if this game were just a regular 3D MMO (as in, totally remove the VR component) then it would be mediocre to laughably bad MMO by standards of 2018,  

Make of that what you will.  It is the most addictive game in occulus that I own.  I have probably played it more than any other two games that I own combined.  If you love VR, have even a passing interest in MMOs or enjoy fantasy RPGs then this game will easily be worth the money you spend.

I've only given it 3 stars because the game itself just isn't there yet.  Too much simplicity in the classes.  There is essentially no development in play from lvl 1 to 20...the same abilities you spam at lvl 1 are the ones you'll spam at lvl 20 (they do more damage or heal for more --- but its the same ones).  Rune Mages can cast the same spells at lvl 1 as they can at max lvl (the system is based on the physical drawing of runes with the wands --- if you can draw the rune you can cast any spell in the game at lvl 1.  again, the damage scales to lvl but not the spell itself).  The lore is relatively simple --- matching the charm of the simple graphics. 

The community is genuinely kind and helpful.  5 stars there for sure.

So let's get the obvious out of the way - this is not a pretty game.  The graphics probably would have been an embarrassment on the original Wii.  That said, the graphics are at least consistent, and it comes together to create a not-bad asthetic overall.  Second, this feels like a very direct port from the HTC Vive, with controls that don't work well with the Oculus.  It's still not terrible, and you get used to them with time, but it feels like it would be a semi-easy thing to optimize closer to other Oculus games (like using the joystick to move/teleport, better button mapping, etc).  I'd be especially interested in a control scheme like The Wizards, with one joystick for teleport and the other for slide movement.  Now, all that being said, the gameplay for this is a lot of fun!  Each class certainly feels very unique, with their own learning curves and challenges.  Memorizing sword skills or runes for casting, or just learning to get the proper distance and aiming with the bow feels like a fun accomplishment.  Being able to switch between classes with separate leveling for each one works very well, much like FFXIV.  The opening quests are a little tedious and almost turned me off to the game, but stick with it and bring a friend, because there are good times to be had (and it becomes SO much easier in a group).  All in all, this one is a good bet as far as early access games go.  Though I doubt the graphics will ever improve much even in the final version, I'm keeping my fingers crossed that they'll figure out better Oculus controls, and then I'm willing to up this to 5 stars.

Descritption: Its a basic MMORPG, nothing special. Tank, DPS, and Support. Walk around in a visually simple world and kill monsters ... and of course ... "Fishing"!
   Cons:
1 - Very basic graphics - But in in VR you don't need impressive graphics. Simpler is better.
2 - Solo play - Not meant for this, it gets boring. Game was not designed for this.
3 - Warrior combos - Spamming combos is what you do. Repetitious and will make your shoulders hurt. In combat you can hear the warrior pant. Game needs to abandon Combos and try something else.
4 - Lack of in game feedback. Not sure if combo works or if you have been hit. Attacks from behind go unnoticed until too late.
5 - Lack on instructions - You got to figure much of it yourself - In an MMO, asking is solves a lot, so don't be shy.
6 - Mage - I drew the glyph exactly as shown to no affect, but a mashed up version works. Game needs improvements here.
7 - Bugs - Voice thing stops working, can't walk through place, but teleport works, etc (Its an alpha build).
   Pros:
1 - Its an MMORPG - Even if you don't like this specific one, supporting it encourages more to be made.
2 - MMO - This is a Pro /Con depending who you meet, but once you find your "Group", its great.
3 - Not spoon fed, its "Old School" - Your map does not show where you are. You need to solve and figure things out on your own (or ask other players). Its about exploring and working together.
4 - Alpha - Its developing and improving. Devs take feedback and are working hard. Ran into a Dev cahracter in game and chatted with him (friendly and informative).
   Conclusion: The Con list may seem long and the Pro list weak; but its interesting and fun when playing with others. Curently, as/is its a 2/3 star, but with Alpha development, its looking like a 4+ game. Did I mention its an MMORPG?

While it’s still in Alpha and does offer a lot of features that MMORPG games do, it’s very simplistic and shallow without much customization. There is still a lot more they need to add and change to justify this $40 price tag. Class skills are given to you from the start, for example archers receive a handful of special arrows which they can equip 2 of at a time. As you level up you never unlock new skills/arrows, you just keep using the same handful throughout. This makes for very boring and repetitive combat. Runemages need to have a complete rework on how skills are handled and casted, or a much higher leniency when trying to draw a pattern otherwise you'll never cast consistently. You do not acquire skill points, and items do not have varying stats. For what it offers and the steep price tag you can’t possibly say this is more than 3 stars. I think people forget that 5 stars means perfect, which this game is not, as I said earlier it’s very simplistic and shallow and missing a lot. If you can get this for $20 then buy it because it is still some fun.

I have played this game over 100 hours. I have a level 10 Musketeer and level 15 Ranger. It is in early access so there are some bugs and incomplete things about the game, hence 4 stars instead of 5. My favorite MMO was Final Fantasy 11 and I haven't enjoyed a game since then as much as I am enjoying this one. Runemage (DPS & Support) was hard at first so I quit for a while but came back to it and started mastering the spells, now I do so much damage those redtails can't touch me (level 2). Musketeer (Healer) was hard at first until I learned how to use the orbs in a rotation that worked. Killing things is a little slow but its a very survivable class. Later on it is impossible to kill healer mobs by yourself at around the same level as you. Ranger (DPS) is now my favorite class. It doesn't do as much DPS as a mage but it is more forgiving and I can usually kill things that are higher level than me (red mark). I haven't spent too much time playing warrior (tank) because I play sitting down in a swivel chair and I have a very small 5 x 5 space where my desk is. Warrior is a very demanding class albeit fun from what I did play of it. I will move my setup so that I can play it more at some point. Talent systems have added character progression in this version that didn't previously exist. 

In short this game is in early access, so if you buy it expect to be dealing with some bugs and minor nuissances. If you love mmorpg games though, there currently is no other game like this one.

Another point to mention is the locomotion system. I have chosen the option to move in the direction of my controller and it's really nice and smooth! In games like from other suns or the new locomotion implemented in Rec Room (move where you look / move independent to sight / controlelrs) it doesn't make me motion sick. Another amazing part is that your quests are written down in a diary and you have to coordinate by a compass and a map (the map is also in the diary). It feels like Morrowind and I missed it so much as you don't have the big bright arrow over your head making you rush from objective to objective without using it (your head). The crafting system is a ... let's say revolution in crafting systems in MMORPGs as you pick the ingredients from a table that is stocked with stuff you deposit in the appropriate chest that is standing beside. Especially alchemy  is whole new feeling in MMORPG crafting as you have the recieps written down in your diary and have to put the ingredients in the pot in the right direction and at the right moment (depends on the temperature that is displayed by the colour of the liquid).
If you want to gain a few muscle in your shoulder and get some stress in not out this is the game for you if not STAY OUT!! but it is FUN

review_title: 100% proof VRMMORPG will be a big thing
one_reviews_text:
This game is awesome! The graphics are meh (why Unity, why not UE4?) and there are a lot of bugs and glitches, but the game mechanics and player interaction are very solid. Questing is fun, while there could be more quests, if you ask me, but it is an early access game. 

This game is the 100% proof that there will be a great VRMMORPG in the future! I played a few nights now and I mean nights from like 22PM to 8AM (this is when my US buddies are online, I'm from germany). It is absolutely addictive when you interact with players. Also becomming a decent rune mage or any other class is a real challenge (rune mage is hardest).

I seriously hope somebody at blizzard tried this game and saw we need WoW VR. 5-10 Blizzard devs and artists can hack together something awesome with their 3D Model database in just a year and everybody will play it night and day I promise. 

Downside is I just came away from my WoW addiction like 8 Years ago and now I know the first real good (not Orbus, but it is a good start) VRMMORPG will kill me xD

Please invest in this game so big companies see there are customers who want VRMMORPG!

Nice open world.

Being a part of a game like this reminds me of the good old days when I started playing text-based MUDs. At the time, there was no internet but once you found a BBS with enough nodes to host multiple people the experience was fantastic. Then came Diablo and LAN parties and finally when WOW came out, I really had to figure out how to have self-control so I could continue to level up in real life. 

This game brings back those early feelings. Adding the virtual layer on top of an MMORPG is terrific! The community has been helpful, and the development team is entirely involved and responsive. I am thrilled that my investment in my Oculus has finally paid off. 

If you can relate to the good old days I have described, you have no choice but to try this game. Just a warning that some self-control is necessary if you want to continue leveling up in the real world.

I've played lots of MMOs and this definitely reminds me of the start of many MMOs out there... like Everquest and to an extent WoW in its early days.  It's not super easy and feels rewarding as you get the hang of what each class can do. Runemage is locked behind a quest, which is good, because if it was your very first try, you'd probably give up in frustration... just know it's the highest damage in the game once you get the hang of it... but it takes a lot of practice to master it. I think there are about 20 spells. I'm proficient in all but 1. you switch classes by switching weapons. so 1 character can play all 4 classes.   I love this game and the developers are VERY good with their open communcation on their forums.  I'm sure that anyone that joins will find lots of people willing to help them out and show them the ropes.

Update 13.03.18:
I am now level 14 (of 20) mage with knowldege but sometimes no skill of my casts :-)
There are quests to do in game to get to this level but not enough. But I read that there will be more coming so future people may find it easier. So I spent several hours in killing Mobs. It made more fun while i was in a group.
To my surprise the story of the game really started at around level 8 ... there were some news coming which I was not expecting. So now I want to see more and get deeper into this story.
I also made the first dungeon which was an interesting experience. If the Tank always jumps in front of the Mob and your cast goes into the Tanks back. You need to find a good position.

It still makes fun playing this game. Not comparable with WoW or other games like this but a good first VR MMORPG.

For where they are at in development I think they deserve 5 stars.  There are some things that I think need to be done better but I can't complain at this point.  VR is not taking off the way it was hoped it would however games like this have the potential to make it happen if they can keep polishing it.  The interactive combat systems are excellent.  You will hear many people complain about the spell casting system but I love it.   A runemage can do a lot of damage if you take the time to practice the spells and remain calm when you are casting regardless of the incoming attacks and you have to remember that you are casting your runes in a 3D world and not 2D so if a spell is flat cast it flat and if it is a 3d spell cast it in 3D.  I do feel that the in game chat system could use some help as I do get tired of listening to the bodily noises coming from peoples open mics.

Basically feels like the worst parts were taken from an MMO and shoved into VR.
As for combat, it's extremely hard to run away, if you play a warrior it basically forces you to sit next to mob and swing until either you or the enemy dies, there's no real tactics to it other than memorizing combos, which don't always seem to execute if your timing is slightly off. If your fighting and another mob wonders over to you, forget about it you're dead. The magic is teribly imprecise as well, some spells I can cast, but apparently I can't even draw a simple "M" to cast a spell, which happens also to be the first letter of my name. This game is much more frustrating than it is fun. It's really not worth it.
I made an account, but it is pretty impossible to actual log in to play.  Gave up.

Ok so, I buy this game for $15 (quite a steal) and don't really know what to expect. I load it up and really enjoy it. It is quite a adventure to learn everything. I love it even though it can get rough when you find yourself at a wall with the leveling design compared to the MSQ design. I am really excited to see the game get updates and I hope that it shapes into the perfect VR game. Give it a try 4/5.

After playing the game for a good 20+ hours I have not felt so excited for a game since I first played World of Warcraft. This is not like World of Warcraft, but it has a sense of discovery, exploration, community and unique combat styles that have inspired me to play as much as possible. There are so many improvements the game can use but it is proof that VRMMORPGs will be immensely successful when the technology becomes more affordable.

If VR wasn't a component this would esentially be "babbies first MMO". Wich isn't necesarily a bad thing since you gota keep it relatively simple for a first attempt. It has some unique ideas though that only work in VR. Spellcasting is very interesting because you have to wave the wand in specific paterns to cast different spells. Archer and musketeer are as expected and fun with VR.

Where I think things need dramatic work is melee. Part of this is a problem I have with most VR games, and thats there is very little feeling you're actually connecting when you swing a weapon (and trying to remember the combos in this is absurd). Another problem would be movement. This game uses the standard design of point and click movement or use the analog stick for incredably fast and jenkey movement. They also use this bizzare system of you moving in the direction of where you hands are pointed rather then the direction of the sticks. Range classes I don't feel are effected as much by this. But in any game melee is dependant on movement. Untill they can work out a better system, this class is very boring, or frustrating.

Overall this is still worth a try for the sake of its potential. Either the potential of this specific game or of future games like it. 

Side note, it would be nice to have an in game option to adjust perspective if you're sitting. Most people don't want to play a MMO for a few hours at a time standing.

I have been playing this game since beta, ever since it was released into EA I havn't played much else.  The game does have a lot of bugs, but once you get over that, the mechanics, community, crafting, and game play are very fun and rewarding.  The game still needs a lot of work, so if you are expecting a perfect game then this one is not for you, but so far the quick responses from the DEV's when something goes wrong has been amazing, and the content changes coming up with the end game dungeons, and the constant patches fixing bugs, I think this game is on the way to be one of the best VR MMORPG's.

INCREDIBLE GAME.   Dont listen to bad reviews.  You get better as you play.  Being good is about getting better at your abilities you master over time.  If everything in the game was easy, it would be a pointless game.

review_title: Most time spent in a VR game
one_reviews_text:
This isn't WoW, but it's the closest to an MMORPG for VR currently on the market. Level progression, loot, gear, crafting, etc. I've spent more time in this game in the last 3 days than I have any other game in the 6 months I've owned the oculus. This is seriously addictive and fun! It does seem to lack a little polish, but it makes up for it with available playtime, classes, quests, online presense, etc.

It's very tempting to skip past a lot of the text when you first start... don't! Read it all the way through - the game is confusing enough and lacks direction a lot of the time, so if you don't pay attention, you miss things pretty easily. 

BE ADVISED: I'm not sure if this will happen for everyone, but I couldn't move or do anything in the world without first configuring the controls (something the game doesn't tell you anything about until you open up the settings). 

Very worth it, very fun, lots of positive, supportive, helpful players online ALWAYS.

EDIT: It's only crashed on me once, and it was a very minor issue... barely an inconvenience. Not sure why it happens so much with everyone else in the reviews.

YES unlike other games Orbus is not learnt in an hour, or even several, practice is everything. That said it got everything an MMORPG needs and is really not that hard. Some classes (like musketeer) are so easy they don't really allow to die if you quest in areas which fit your level. As in any other RPG, use your abilities (orbs) correctly, specially the shield one and the turret set to healing NOT dmg. Easy to pass through all the mobs, solo, quickly. Ranger isn't much harder, this one does a ton of dmg, I'd perhaps watch some videos first to get a grip. Now the mage class is hardest and hidden behind a rock and quests for a reason(!), this one I would not even try before leveling another class at least to level 5 or 6 first. Then again it is about figuring the most effective order of spells, and practice. The warrior is kind of exhausting, I chose the girly-class (healer/musketeer) which I like most so far and well, i'm just not sportive enough to play the others more than 1-2 hours in a row :). The biggest advantage: Most VR games are cool, but either content is done in few hours or shorter or they get boring. Orbus will keep you goin for 100+ hours I'm sure, once you got the hang of it. Graphics are rather simple yet I prefer a stable server featuring multiplayer over a fancy bells-n-whistles game which crashes all the time. Some things I'm hoping for is for example improvement of controls (changing class and armor takes way too long imo), but hey awesome job for an EA game, something I missed for like 2 years is finally there!
I like how this game plays. The VR and controls are adequate but could use some work. Community seems friendly. I'm excited to see where they go with this as it has a lot of potential.
